wikipedia_page.main: Hugh Watt (1848 – 16 March 1921) was a Scottish merchant and Liberal politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1885 to 1892. His career ended in scandal and imprisonment.

response: His daughter Violet married Reginald Proctor-Beauchamp (1853-1912) in 1880. They had two daughters. In 1896 her husband filed for divorce, naming Hugh Watt, a former Member of Parliament for Glasgow, as a co-respondent; the divorce was granted in 1901The Titled Nobility of Europe: An International Peerage...", Part 1, Marquis de Ruvigny, London: Harrison & Sons, 1914, p. 1237 and Proctor-Beauchamp was awarded ten thousand pounds in a suit against Watt for criminal conversation. Watt's wife also divorced him. After his wife refused for many years to finalize the divorce, Watt was convicted of plotting to murder her in 1905. He was released after a year amid public sentiment that the conviction was based on false testimony."Robert Jocelyn Receives a Title", The Times Dispatch (Richmond, Virginia), July 18, 1910, p. 4 The divorce was finally completed and Violet married him after his release from prison in 1906.https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/08/19/101706193.pdf "Murder Plot Charged Against Hugh Watt", New York Times, August 19, 1905
